The salt-scour of the air was a constant rasp in the throat. In Portsmouth, you breathed the sea. You tasted it on your lips when the wind blew in off the Solent, a gritty, damp flavour that clung to everything – brickwork, skin, memory. Alfie knew the taste better than any other. It was the taste of his life, a thin gruel of a flavour he could never quite wash away. He walked with his head down, shoulders hunched against a wind that wasn't there, a habit learned in the narrow, brawling streets that bled from the docks. The gulls screamed overhead, sounding less like birds and more like frantic, lost souls.

Today, the smell was different. Thicker. Beneath the brine and the diesel fumes from the harbour, another scent wormed its way into the air. A coppery, organic tang that made the back of Alfie’s tongue feel heavy and thick. He knew it before he saw it. His stomach gave a preliminary lurch, a warning shot across the bow. He risked a glance up. Ahead, outside the frosted glass of the Shipwright’s Arms, a knot of men had gathered. Laughter, loud and guttural, bounced off the slick cobbles. In their midst, a fisherman, built like a barrel, was holding court. He’d just come from the market, his apron a Jackson Pollock of gore. He was regaling his mates with a story, punctuating it with a sweep of a blood-slicked hand. A fine spray of red misted the air, catching the weak afternoon light like a cloud of tiny, terrible jewels.

Alfie’s breath hitched. The world tilted, the grey sky seeming to press down, the sound of the gulls warping into a high-pitched whine that drilled directly into his skull. The cobbles under his feet felt suddenly unstable, like the deck of a ship in a heavy swell. It was the red. The sheer, unapologetic redness of it. The way it clung to the man’s knuckles, the way it had beaded on the stray bristles of his beard. It wasn’t just a colour. It was a presence. A liquid threat.

He stumbled back, one hand flying to his mouth as his stomach churned with violent intent. The men’s laughter followed him, though it wasn’t directed at him. They hadn’t even noticed the skinny, pale boy recoiling from their orbit. To them, he was just another piece of the grimy scenery. But their oblivious cheer felt like a personal mockery. *Look at the blood. It’s nothing. It’s life. It’s work. What’s wrong with you?*

He turned, half-walking, half-falling, into a side alley that smelled of stale beer and urine. He braced himself against a brick wall, the rough texture biting into his palms. He squeezed his eyes shut, but the image was seared onto the backs of his eyelids: the spray of red, the dark patches on the apron, the glistening smear on a smiling man’s hand. He concentrated on breathing. In through the nose, out through the mouth. The mantra of a thousand similar moments. The air was foul, but it was air. It wasn't red. He stayed there for a long time, listening to his own heart hammer against his ribs like a trapped bird, waiting for the world to stop spinning.

The Davison’s house was on a street of tired-looking terraces, each one identical to the last, distinguished only by the varying shades of their peeling front doors. Theirs was a particularly morose shade of green, the colour of a stagnant pond. Inside, the air was always thick with the ghost of boiled vegetables and Mr. Davison’s disapproval. Alfie let himself in, the click of the latch unnaturally loud in the hallway’s gloom.

“That you, Alfie?” Mrs. Davison’s voice, thin and perpetually worried, drifted from the kitchen.

“Yes,” he managed, his own voice a croak.

He could hear the rustle of a newspaper from the front room. Mr. Davison was home. Of course he was. Alfie slipped off his worn trainers, placing them neatly by the door, a small, pointless act of appeasement. He just wanted to get up to his room, the small box at the top of the house that overlooked a patchwork of mossy roofs and tangled washing lines. But he knew the ritual. He had to present himself.

He pushed open the door to the front room. Robert Davison sat in his armchair, the one with the permanent indentation of his body, the day’s paper held up like a shield. He lowered it an inch, his eyes, small and hard like pebbles, fixing on Alfie.

“Well?” The single word was an accusation.

Alfie’s stomach, finally settled, began to clench again. “Nothing today. At the cannery. They said maybe next week.” It was a lie. He hadn’t even made it to the cannery. He’d meant to. But after the incident outside the pub, the very idea of the place, with its endless parade of slit, gutted fish, was unthinkable.

Mr. Davison made a sound, a sort of tutting noise deep in his chest. “Can’t be afraid of getting your hands dirty, lad. The world doesn’t hand you things on a plate. Not for the likes of us.” He rustled the paper, a gesture of dismissal. The unspoken accusation hung in the air between them: *Weak. You’re weak.* Mr. Davison was a man of simple, brutal truths. Work was work. Blood was part of it, whether you were a soldier, a butcher, or a fisherman. To be afraid of it was to be afraid of life itself. It was a moral failing.

Alfie just nodded, his gaze fixed on a worn patch of carpet. “I know.”

The back door slammed shut, rattling the glass in the kitchen door. A sudden whirlwind of energy blew into the house, and with it, the scent of fresh air and something wilder, like damp earth and crushed leaves. Clara.

She appeared in the doorway of the front room, her cheeks flushed from the cold, her dark hair a tangled mess that she hadn’t bothered to tame. She was a year younger than Alfie, but she seemed to take up twice the space, brimming with a vitality that felt almost aggressive in the house’s oppressive quiet. Her eyes, a sharp, intelligent blue, took in the scene at a glance: Alfie, pale and shrinking; her father, stern and implacable behind his paper.

“Leave him alone, Dad,” she said, her voice clear and cutting. There was no pleading in it, only command. She kicked off her muddy boots in the hallway with a series of loud thumps, a deliberate act of defiance.

“I’m just telling the boy a fact of life, Clara,” Mr. Davison said, not looking at her. “Something you could stand to learn yourself.”

“I know all about facts,” she retorted, marching into the kitchen. They could hear her talking to her mother, her voice a low, furious murmur. A moment later, she was back, pressing a mug of steaming tea into Alfie’s cold hands. “You look like you’ve seen a ghost.”

Alfie flinched at the word, but her presence was a balm. She was solid. Real. She wasn’t afraid of anything. “Just tired,” he mumbled, the warmth of the mug a small comfort.

“Heard about a job down at the marina,” she said, her voice dropping so their father couldn’t hear. “Sanding hulls. No blood. Just dust. Old Man Hemlock is looking for someone. I’ll take you down tomorrow.”

She looked at him, and for a second, her fierce expression softened. She saw the tremor in his hands, the bruised look around his eyes. She didn’t understand it, not really. Alfie knew that. To her, blood was just blood. She’d once set his dislocated finger herself after a fall, her face a mask of concentration, not a flicker of disgust. But she accepted his fear as a fact, like his height or the colour of his eyes. She didn’t try to explain it or cure it. She just built a wall around it, and dared anyone to try and breach it.

“Okay,” he whispered, the single word a surrender and a thank you all at once.

Later, the house settled into its usual evening rhythm. The clatter of plates, the drone of the television, the suffocating silence. Alfie lay on his narrow bed, listening to the house breathe around him. He could hear the faint murmur of Clara’s radio from her room next door. She was his step-sister. That was the official term. His mother had died, a long, slow fading he barely remembered. His father… well, his father had been a ghost long before he’d disappeared entirely. Then came the orphanage, a grey blur of years. And then the Davisons. They’d fostered Clara first, a spitfire of a girl nobody else could handle. And then, a year later, they’d taken him, too. A quiet, haunted boy to balance the equation. They weren’t family, not really. They were a collection of shipwrecked people who had washed up in the same house.

But Clara… Clara felt like an anchor. Even when she was causing a storm, she was the one solid thing in his drifting life. He couldn’t remember a time before her. That part of his life was a blank, a fogged-over window he never tried to wipe clean. His memory started with her, with her grabbing his hand on his first day at the Davisons’, her small face set with grim determination as she announced, “You’re with me now.”

He turned onto his side, the mattress springs groaning in protest. The image from the street flashed behind his eyes again. The red. The bright, living red. His heart gave a familiar, sickening flutter. Why? Where did it come from, this terror? Other boys got into fights, came home with split lips and bloody noses and wore them like badges of honour. He saw a papercut and felt the world fall away. It made no sense. It was a flaw in his design, a wire crossed somewhere deep inside him. He pressed his face into the thin, lumpy pillow, trying to force the images out, trying to replace them with the thought of sanding hulls. Dust. He could handle dust. Dust was the past. It was dead and dry and harmless. It wasn't wet and red and screaming with life. The distant foghorn moaned from the harbour, a long, low note of loss that seemed to echo the hollow space inside his own chest. He just had to get through the night. Then he could focus on the dust.The next morning broke grey and grudging, the light filtering through Alfie’s grimy window pane as if exhausted by the effort. For a few blessed moments, suspended in the quiet space between sleep and waking, he was just a boy in a bed. Then the memory of the fisherman’s apron returned, a phantom splash of red, and his stomach tightened. He pushed himself up, the cold floorboards a shock to his bare feet. Outside, the gulls were already at their work, their cries weaving into the distant, rhythmic clang of a hammer on steel from the naval dockyard. The sound of industry, of men at work. The sound of Mr. Davison’s disappointment.

He dressed quickly and crept downstairs. The house was cold, holding the night’s chill in its bones. Clara was already in the kitchen, a starkly energetic figure against the peeling yellow paint. She sat at the small table, a half-eaten piece of toast in one hand, her muddy boots from the day before already laced up and ready. She looked up as he entered, her blue eyes assessing him in a swift, clinical glance. She didn't comment on his pallor or the shadows under his eyes. She just nodded towards the kettle.

"Tea's brewed. Drink it fast. I want to get there before he finds something else to do," she said, her voice a low conspiratorial murmur. She didn't need to say who 'he' was. From the front room, the rustle of newspaper was an early warning signal. Mrs. Davison moved like a wraith between the stove and the sink, her expression one of habitual, low-grade anxiety. She gave Alfie a watery smile but said nothing, a silent bystander in the daily tensions of her own home. Alfie gulped down the hot, sweet tea, the warmth a temporary truce with his churning insides. Clara was already on her feet, grabbing her coat. "Let's go."

Outside, the air was sharp and clean. A brisk wind had scoured the thick, coppery smell from the streets, leaving only the familiar tang of salt and cold stone. Clara set a punishing pace, her long strides eating up the pavement. Alfie, shorter and slighter, almost had to jog to keep up. She strode through the streets as if she owned them, her chin up, her gaze direct, while Alfie kept to his usual habit, eyes down, watching the cracks in the paving stones, navigating the world at his feet. They passed the Shipwright’s Arms, its windows dark and empty now. The cobbles were washed clean by an overnight shower, all traces of yesterday’s horror gone as if it had never been.

"Dad's just scared, you know," Clara said suddenly, not looking at him. Her voice was uncharacteristically soft, robbed of its usual sharp edge by the wind. "He worked in the yards his whole life. Got laid off five years ago. Now he just sits there, stewing. He sees you, and I think he's just terrified you'll end up like him. Sitting. Waiting." It was the most she had ever offered by way of an explanation for her father’s bitterness. It wasn’t an excuse, just a fact, presented with the same straightforwardness she applied to everything.

The marina was a different world from the commercial docks. Here, the boats were for pleasure, not for industry. A forest of slender white masts pointed to the sky, their rigging tinkling a gentle, metallic music in the wind. The air smelled of salt, but also of varnish, fibreglass, and drying paint. It was a clean, chemical smell, the smell of preservation, not slaughter. Alfie felt the knot in his chest loosen a little. They walked along a pontoon, the wooden planks bouncing slightly under their feet, until Clara pointed towards a small, cluttered boatyard set back from the water. In the middle of the yard, a man who looked as though he'd been carved from driftwood was wrestling with a sheet of canvas, his face a roadmap of wrinkles, his arms ropy with muscle. That had to be Hemlock.

Clara marched right up to him. "Mr. Hemlock? I'm Clara Davison. I heard you were looking for a hand." Her directness seemed to startle the old man. He stopped fighting the canvas and straightened up, grunting with the effort. He squinted at her, then his gaze shifted to Alfie, who was hovering a few paces behind her like a nervous shadow. Hemlock’s eyes, pale and washed out as sea-glass, raked over Alfie, taking in the skinny frame, the worn clothes, the pale face. His expression was not encouraging.

"I'm looking for a worker, girl, not a stray to feed," he rasped, his voice like stones grinding together. "He looks like a good wind would blow him over."

"He's stronger than he looks," Clara shot back, her hands on her hips. "And he's a hard worker. He just needs a chance. He won't give you any trouble." Alfie felt a hot flush of shame creep up his neck. He was being discussed like a piece of faulty equipment. He forced himself to meet the old man's gaze.

"I'll work," Alfie said, his voice quiet but clear. "Whatever you need."

Hemlock grunted again, a sound of deep skepticism. He gestured with a gnarled thumb towards a small sailing boat propped up on wooden struts. Its hull was a patchwork of old, flaking blue paint and underlying white primer. "Know what a sander is, boy?" Alfie nodded. "Right. That hull needs taking back. All of it. Pay you at the end of the day if you've done an honest day's work. If not, you don't come back." He turned and picked up a heavy-duty electric sander from a workbench, its cord coiled like a sleeping snake. He thrust it at Alfie. It was heavy, solid. Alfie took it, his fingers closing around the plastic grip.

He walked over to the boat, his heart thumping a nervous rhythm against his ribs. This was it. A real chance. He plugged the cord into an extension lead, the sander buzzing to life in his hands with a loud, angry snarl. He flinched at the noise, but held it steady. He touched the spinning disc to the hull. A cloud of blue and white dust immediately billowed into the air, and a patch of pale, naked wood appeared. The dust smelled dry, chalky, ancient. It coated his hands, his clothes, filled his nostrils. It was the colour of ghosts, of things that were over. Alfie took a deep breath. He could handle this. He leaned into the work, the roar of the machine filling his head, the vibration travelling up his arms. He focused on the patch of blue in front of him, on the simple, honest task of erasing it, and for the first time in a long time, the world shrank to a space he could control.The machine was a roaring beast in his hands, but it was a beast he could command. The vibration travelled up his arms and settled in his shoulders, a deep, thrumming ache that felt honest and real. He braced himself against the hull and leaned into the work, the angry snarl of the sander drowning out the gulls, the wind, and the frantic monologue in his own head. A fine powder, a mix of ghostly white and tired blue, filled the air around him, coating his hair and clothes in a uniform grey. He tasted the chalky grit on his tongue and didn't mind. He was erasing. With every pass of the machine, he was wiping away the flaking, peeling past, taking the boat back to its original, naked self. It was a clean, simple violence, and it was deeply satisfying.

Hours passed in a loud, vibrating blur. The sun climbed higher, warming his back. His arms, unused to the strain, began to burn with a fire that spread to his spine. Sweat trickled down his temples, carving clean paths through the layers of dust on his skin. Around noon, the roar of the sander died as he switched it off to give his aching hands a rest. The sudden silence was immense, deafening. In the quiet, he could hear the gentle slap of water against the pontoons and the distant, lonely cry of a tern. He stepped back to look at his work. A huge swathe of the hull, nearly half of one side, was now a pale, raw wood, smooth to the eye. It was his. He had done that. From the doorway of a cramped workshop that smelled of turpentine and old rope, Mr. Hemlock watched him, a steaming mug cradled in his hands. The old man didn't speak, just gave a slow, assessing nod, a gesture so minimal it was almost not there at all, before turning and disappearing back into the shadows.

He ran a hand over the newly smooth surface, feeling the clean grain of the wood under his dusty fingers. A mistake. A sharp, stinging pain shot through his palm. He pulled his hand back as if bitten. A long, wicked-looking splinter of wood was embedded deep in the fleshy part of his thumb. He froze, his heart giving a single, hard jolt against his ribs. Panic, cold and familiar, began to rise in his throat. He stared at the foreign object lodged in his skin, his mind starting its frantic spiral. But this was different. This wasn't a stranger’s gore, it wasn't a sudden, shocking spray of red. This was a direct consequence of his own labour. His own work. Taking a shaky breath, he gritted his teeth, pinched the end of the splinter between his other thumb and forefinger, and pulled. It came out cleanly, leaving a tiny, perfect hole. A single, dark bead of blood welled up, shockingly red against his grimy skin. Alfie stared at it, mesmerised. The world did not tilt. The sky did not press down. It was just a drop. His drop. He brought his thumb to his mouth and sucked the wound, the coppery taste a small, private fact. It was a part of the job. He found a relatively clean rag, wrapped it tightly around his thumb, and picked up the sander again.

When the afternoon light began to fail, turning the water in the marina to a sheet of dull pewter, every muscle in Alfie’s body screamed in protest. He had finished the entire side of the boat. It stood before him, pale and uniform, waiting for its next coat, its new life. He was unplugging the sander when Hemlock emerged from the workshop, wiping his hands on an oily cloth. The old man walked over to the hull without a word, his critical gaze sweeping over the boat. He ran a gnarled, expert hand along the length of the wood, feeling for imperfections. Alfie held his breath. Hemlock grunted, a sound that conveyed neither approval nor disapproval. He turned to Alfie, his sea-glass eyes appraising him once more. Then, he reached into the deep pocket of his canvas trousers and pulled out a small, heavy handful of coins. He pressed them firmly into Alfie’s filthy, open palm.

"Be here eight tomorrow," the old man rasped. "We'll do the other side." He paused, looking at the fine layer of dust that covered Alfie from head to toe. "And find a mask. Don't want to be coughing your lungs up." It was the closest thing to kindness the man was likely capable of. Alfie could only nod, his throat too tight to form words. He closed his hand around the coins. They were heavy, real. He had earned this weight. He had traded his aches and his sweat and a single drop of his own blood for it, and it felt like the best bargain he had ever made.

The walk home was a slow, deliberate march against the pull of his own exhaustion. The ache in his shoulders and back was a constant, thrumming reminder of his day’s labour. He kept one hand in his pocket, his fingers curled around the coins, turning them over and over. The metal was cool against his skin, a solid talisman against the anxieties that usually haunted his steps. For the first time he could remember, he walked with his head up, watching the streetlights flicker on one by one against the deepening twilight. He was no longer just a ghost drifting through Portsmouth’s grimy streets. He was Alfie, a boy who sanded hulls. The salt in the air didn’t rasp in his throat; it was just the evening air, tasting of the sea.

He opened the front door to the Davison’s house, and the familiar smell of boiled cabbage and disappointment hit him like a physical blow. The quiet inside was heavy, oppressive. He slipped off his trainers, leaving dusty footprints on the worn lino. From the front room, the rustle of the newspaper stopped. Mr. Davison was waiting. "Well?" The single word, sharp and accusatory, cut through the gloom. Alfie didn't answer. Instead, he walked to the doorway of the front room. He met Robert Davison's hard, pebble-like gaze for a single, fleeting second. Then, he stepped forward and placed the coins he had earned onto the small, cluttered side table next to the man’s armchair. The clatter of metal on wood was unnaturally loud, a declaration. He didn't wait for a reaction. He turned, his back straight, and walked up the stairs, the day's honest aches a suit of armour against any unspoken condemnation.Up in his room, the world shrank to the size of the narrow bed and the square of sky in the window. The ache in his bones was a deep and unfamiliar song, a bass note that resonated from his shoulders down to his ankles. It was a good pain. It was the opposite of the hollow, frantic feeling of anxiety that usually occupied his body. This pain was solid. It was proof. He stripped off his dusty clothes, shaking them out of the window and watching the grey powder disperse into the twilight like a flock of departing ghosts. In the small, shared bathroom, he washed his hands and arms under a stream of cold water, watching the grime sluice away in grey rivers down the drain. He was pale underneath, but it was his own skin, no longer hidden under a layer of the day’s labour. The small, neat puncture on his thumb from the splinter was a tiny, dark red mouth, already sealed shut. He touched it gently. It was a mark of ownership.

He had just pulled on a clean shirt when his door creaked open. Clara stood there, silhouetted against the dim light of the landing. She held a plate with two thick sandwiches on it. She didn't say anything at first, just walked in and set the plate on his small bedside table. Her eyes, sharp and knowing, took in his exhausted slump, the way he held his shoulders.

"Heard the thunderclap downstairs," she said, a small smile playing on her lips. "Thought the roof might cave in from the shock." She nodded towards the plate. "Mum made these. She was too scared to bring them up herself."

Alfie picked up a sandwich. Roast beef. A luxury usually reserved for Sundays. "What did he do?" he asked, his voice rough with dust and tiredness.

"Nothing," Clara said, and that was the most shocking thing of all. "He just sat there. Stared at the coins for about five minutes. Then he picked them up, put them in his pocket, and turned the page of his paper." She sat on the end of his bed, the springs groaning under her weight. "He didn't say a word. Mum tried to start a conversation about the gas bill, and he just grunted. It's a new record for quietest Tuesday in Davison history." She nudged his foot with her own. "So. Old Man Hemlock didn't work you to death, then."

"Almost," Alfie admitted, taking a large bite of the sandwich. He was ravenous. "I have to be there at eight tomorrow."

"Good." She saw him flex his aching hand and her gaze sharpened, dropping to the small, dark mark on his thumb. "You hurt yourself." It wasn't an accusation or a worried fuss, just a statement of fact.

"Just a splinter," he said, suddenly defensive. "It's nothing."

She looked from the mark on his hand to his face, and a flicker of something – not pity, but a deep, fierce understanding – passed through her expression. She knew what it cost him to say those words, to dismiss a wound, however small. "Well," she said, getting to her feet. "Don't let him see it. He'll think you're clumsy." The ‘he’ was Hemlock, but it could have been her father. It could have been the whole world. With a final, appraising look, she left, closing the door softly behind her. Alfie finished the sandwiches in the quiet of his room, the unfamiliar weight of earned food in his stomach. Later, lying in the dark, he listened to the house. It was different. The usual drone of the television from the front room was absent. There was only a profound, waiting silence, as if his small handful of coins had broken the house's miserable rhythm, and it didn't yet know the new beat.

Waking the next day was an agony. Every muscle he hadn't known he possessed staged a stiff, painful protest. Rolling out of bed felt like a complex gymnastic feat. For a moment, the thought of the sander, of the hours of vibration and dust, was unbearable. But then he remembered the weight of the coins and Hemlock’s grudging words: *Be here eight tomorrow*. It was an order, but it was also a promise. He had a place to be. He forced his complaining body down the stairs. The kitchen was empty save for Mrs. Davison, who gave him a quick, nervous smile and pushed a cup of tea into his hand, her movements even more bird-like than usual. The door to the front room was ajar. As Alfie passed, he saw Mr. Davison in his armchair, not reading the paper, but cleaning a pair of old work boots with a fierce, concentrated energy, as if trying to scrub away years of disuse. He didn't look up, and for the first time, there was no "Well?" to cut through the morning air. The silence was its own complicated language.

The air at the marina was cold and damp, a fresh breeze blowing in off the water. Hemlock was standing by the boat, a dark shape in the morning grey. As Alfie approached, the old man turned and held something out to him. It was a proper respirator mask with two round filters on the sides, looking like the snout of some strange insect. "Put this on," Hemlock grunted. "You breathe in enough of that dust, you'll be coughing up your guts for a week. Don't need a sick boy on my hands." Alfie took it, the gesture of rough-hewn care leaving him momentarily speechless. He fitted the mask over his nose and mouth, the rubber sealing coldly against his skin. The air he breathed was suddenly filtered, clean, tasting faintly of plastic. It felt like another layer of armour.

The work was just as hard as the day before, but the rhythm came more easily. He knew the machine now, knew how to hold it so the vibration didn't numb his hands completely, how to shift his weight to ease the ache in his back. He was no longer just a boy holding a tool; he and the sander were partners in the act of erasure. The second side of the hull began to shed its skin under his methodical guidance. The world beyond his mask and the roar of the machine ceased to exist. Around midday, he switched off the sander and pulled off the mask, his face damp with sweat. He sat on an upturned crate, his muscles trembling with fatigue, and watched the life of the marina. A few boats down, a man in bright yellow oilskins was unloading his catch from a small fishing trawler. He began to clean them right there on the pontoon, his movements swift and practiced. A quick slice, a spill of dark guts into a bucket. Alfie’s breath caught in his throat. The familiar cold dread began to seep into his limbs. His eyes were fixed on the man's hands, on the knife, on the slick, dark mess. He felt the urge to run, to turn and hide in the dusty sanctuary of the boatyard. But he was tired. His body was a solid, aching weight, grounding him to the spot. He was too exhausted to panic properly. He stayed where he was, his heart hammering a frantic beat against his ribs, and he watched. From this distance, the horror was muted. It wasn't a chaotic spray of red mist; it was a process. A messy, grim, but methodical process. It was work. He watched for thirty seconds, a lifetime, before he made himself look away, his gaze falling on his own dusty, capable hands. He had not fallen. The world had not ended.

He needed more sanding discs. Hemlock had pointed him towards the workshop, a cavernous, cluttered space that smelled powerfully of things old and useful: rope, oil, wood shavings, and something else, a sharp, piercing chemical scent. Turpentine. Alfie stepped inside, his eyes adjusting to the gloom. The smell was overpowering, clean and volatile. As he breathed it in, the world lurched, but not in the way it did with the red. It was a different kind of shift, a sideways slip in time. For a single, blinding second, he was not in a boatyard workshop. He was in a warm, dark room. He saw polished wood, the deep red of a velvet chair, and the glint of yellow lamplight on the neck of a glass bottle. The air was thick with the exact same smell of turpentine, mixed with cigar smoke and something else, something sweet, like perfume. A woman’s laugh, low and musical, echoed in the space. Then, just as quickly, it was gone. He was standing in Hemlock’s dusty workshop, blinking, a profound sense of disorientation washing over him. The vision had been more than a thought; it had been a feeling, a full-sensory echo from a place he couldn’t name. It felt real. It felt like a memory, but from before. Before the fog. He stood frozen for a long moment, the scent of turpentine clinging to him like a question he didn't know how to ask.The clatter of sanding discs brought him back. He was in Hemlock’s workshop. The air was thick with the scent that had ambushed him. He grabbed a handful of the rough, circular papers from a box, his movements stiff and automatic. The vision, or whatever it was, clung to him like the dust on his clothes. It wasn't frightening like the red was. It was profoundly unsettling, a glimpse into a room he felt he knew intimately but could not place, a ghost of a life that wasn't his. The woman's laugh echoed in the hollows of his memory, a sound of pure, uncomplicated joy that felt utterly alien. He backed out of the workshop, the smell of turpentine seeming to follow him, clinging to the inside of his nostrils.

He fitted a new disc and returned to the hull, pulling the respirator mask over his face. The filtered air was a relief, but the phantom scent remained, a chemical ghost in his mind. He threw himself into the work with a new kind of desperation. Before, the noise of the sander had been a way to drown out the fear of the outside world. Now, it was a way to silence the questions erupting inside him. Who was that woman? What was that room? Why did a smell he'd never consciously encountered before feel more familiar than his own reflection? The work became a frantic meditation. The ache returned to his arms and back, a welcome, grounding pain. He focused on the wood, on the line between old paint and new surface, on the simple, physical truth of his labour. But with every breath, he tasted turpentine.

Late in the afternoon, as he was finishing the last section of the hull, he saw Mr. Hemlock talking to the fisherman from the pontoon. The man's yellow oilskins were smeared with dark patches, his hands busy gesturing as he spoke. Alfie’s stomach gave a familiar, sickening clench. He kept the sander running, the roar a shield, but he watched them from the corner of his eye. The fisherman laughed, a hearty sound that carried over the noise of the machine, and clapped Hemlock on the shoulder, leaving a faint, dark smear on the old man’s canvas jacket. Alfie froze, waiting for the world to tilt, for the whine to drill into his skull. He felt the flutter of panic, the cold sweat on his neck. But it was different. It was as if he were watching it happen to someone else, a character in a film. The visceral, gut-wrenching terror was blunted, muted by the deep ache in his muscles and the strange, persistent memory of turpentine and lamplight that now occupied the forefront of his mind. The red was still a threat, but it was no longer the only monster in the room.

At the end of the day, Hemlock paid him again, the same solid weight of coins pressed into his palm. The old man glanced at the dark smear on his own jacket, then at Alfie’s pale, watchful face. He seemed to understand something, though it was impossible to know what went on behind those sea-glass eyes. "A man's work is his own," Hemlock said, his voice a low rasp. "Don't matter what it is. Fisherman, boatwright, king. You do the job in front of you." He looked at the now completely stripped hull, its pale wood glowing in the last of the light. "We'll prime tomorrow. Different job. Quieter." He turned and walked back to his workshop without another word.

The walk home was a blur of competing sensations. The solid weight of the coins in his pocket, the deep, satisfying ache of a body pushed to its limits, and the ghostly scent of turpentine that rose and fell with his own breathing. The memory fragment played on a loop behind his eyes: red velvet, yellow light, a woman's laugh. It was a puzzle box he had just discovered inside himself, and he had no idea how to open it. He passed a hardware shop, its windows cluttered with tools and tins of paint, and the scent of turpentine wafted out, stronger this time, mingling with the smell of sawdust. He stopped, his heart thudding. It was the same smell. The memory flickered, stronger this time, almost close enough to touch. He felt a sudden, desperate urge to understand.

When he got back to the Davisons’, the house was still caught in its new, strange quiet. He placed his earnings on the side table next to Mr. Davison’s chair, the clatter of the coins now a familiar, evening ritual. This time, Mr. Davison looked up from his paper and gave a curt, almost imperceptible nod. It was a seismic event. Alfie went up to his room, his mind racing. The blood-fear had defined his entire existence, a high-walled prison he could never escape. But today, something else had breached the walls. A clue. A scent. The fear was still there, a sleeping dragon in the pit of his stomach, but now there was something else, too. A question that needed an answer. The past was no longer a blank, terrifying fog. It had a smell. After he’d washed the day’s dust away, he found Clara in the kitchen, poring over a tattered map of the coastline.

"Where would you get turpentine?" he asked, the words coming out in a rush before he could stop them. Clara looked up, surprised by his directness. "For a job?" she asked, her blue eyes curious. "Hardware store. Art shop, maybe. Why?" He couldn't explain the vision, the feeling, the woman's laugh. It was too new, too fragile. It was his alone. "I just... I like the smell," he lied, the excuse sounding flimsy even to his own ears. Clara gave him a long, searching look. She knew it was a lie, but she also seemed to sense that this wasn't about fear. It was about something else. She tapped a spot on the map with her finger. "There's an old art supply shop on Palmerston Road. Been there forever. The dusty kind of place that smells of oil paint and chemicals. If you like that sort of thing."

He nodded, a plan solidifying in his mind. He would take some of his money, the money he had earned with his own two hands, and he would go to that shop. He wouldn't just be a boy running from something. He would be a boy walking towards something. He would stand in that shop and breathe in that smell, and he would see what happened. He would see if he could find the key to that warm, lamplit room. He would try to find his way back into his own memory.The next morning, the ritual of the coins felt different. Standing in the cold hallway, the weight of the day’s future earnings already settling in his aching shoulders, Alfie made a decision. It was a quiet, internal rebellion, as profound and terrifying as stepping off a ledge. He held the small pile of metal Hemlock had given him, the result of a day spent wrestling with the roaring sander. With trembling fingers, he separated two of the larger coins and slipped them deep into the pocket of his thin trousers. The metal felt cold against his leg, a secret weight. He then walked to the front room and placed the remaining money on the side table. The clatter was lighter than before, a diminished offering. Mr. Davison, already seated in his armchair, lowered his paper. His hard eyes flickered from the coins to Alfie’s face. Alfie braced himself for the inevitable question, the accusation. But it didn't come. Mr. Davison just stared for a long moment, a flicker of something unreadable in his gaze – calculation, perhaps, or even a grudging respect. He grunted, a sound deep in his chest, and raised his paper again. The shield was back in place. Alfie escaped upstairs to grab his coat, his heart hammering. He had stolen from the household fund. He had claimed a part of his own earnings for himself. He was a thief, and he had never felt more powerful.

The work that day was priming. The hull, stripped bare and vulnerable, needed its first protective coat. Hemlock handed him a wide brush and a heavy can of white primer. The job was quieter, more meticulous. There was no roaring machine to hide inside, only the rhythmic slap of the brush against wood, the soft suck and release of bristles. The air smelled of chemicals and paint, a clean, sterile scent that did little to cover the persistent phantom of turpentine in his mind. The quiet allowed his thoughts to roam. As he worked, his movements becoming steady and methodical, the memory fragment from the workshop returned, clearer and more insistent. The red velvet chair. The golden light. The woman's musical laugh. And now, something new. A man's voice, low and warm, with a hint of amusement. *“Careful, now. It’s a living thing.”* The words hung in the air of his mind, as real as the slap of the brush in his hand. Whose voice? What was a living thing? A painting? He dipped his brush, spreading a smooth, perfect layer of white over the raw wood, covering it, protecting it. He was covering things up, while all he wanted to do was uncover them.

He left the marina with his secret coins heavy in his pocket, the fresh primer on the boat gleaming a ghostly white in the fading light. He didn’t turn towards home. He turned towards the town centre, towards Palmerston Road. Every step was a conscious choice, a deviation from the rutted track of his life. The streets were crowded with people heading home from work, their faces grey with fatigue. Alfie moved among them, a small, anonymous boy on a secret mission. He felt a nervous energy thrumming just beneath his skin, a feeling that was equal parts terror and exhilaration. He found the art shop just as Clara had described it, tucked between a bustling bakery and a dark-looking pub. Its sign was faded, the gold-leaf lettering peeling, and the window display was a chaotic jumble of canvases, clay-dusted tools, and pots of dried-up brushes. It looked like a place that had forgotten about the passage of time.

Taking a deep breath that did nothing to steady him, he pushed open the door. A small bell chimed, a delicate, silver sound that was utterly alien to the world of groaning ships and screaming gulls he knew. The air inside hit him at once. It was thick, layered, ancient. It was the smell from his memory, but a thousand times richer. The sharp, clean spike of turpentine was the top note, but beneath it lay a complex symphony of other scents: the nutty, sweet smell of linseed oil, the dry, earthy aroma of pigments, the dusty perfume of old paper and wood. The shop was a narrow, deep cavern of treasures, shelves groaning under the weight of paint tubes arranged in rainbows of colour, stacks of paper, and wooden boxes of charcoal. It was a quiet, colourful, and intensely scented world. He stood just inside the door, utterly overwhelmed, feeling like a creature of the grey docks who had stumbled into a tropical jungle.

From the shadowy depths of the shop, a man emerged, wiping his hands on a paint-smeared rag. He was old, with a cascade of white hair and a face as kind and crumpled as old parchment. "Can I help you, young man?" he asked, his voice soft. Alfie’s own voice felt trapped in his throat. He felt the man's gentle, curious gaze on his dusty clothes, his work-worn hands. He was an intruder here. "I'm... looking for turpentine," he managed, the words a barely audible croak. The man smiled, a genuine, warm expression. "Artists' grade or the rough stuff for cleaning brushes?" Alfie had no idea. "Just... a small bottle," he stammered. The shopkeeper nodded and led him towards the back, his soft-soled shoes making no sound on the wooden floorboards. As they moved deeper into the shop, the scent grew stronger, more concentrated. Alfie felt a wave of dizziness. The lamplit room from his memory bloomed behind his eyes, vivid and overwhelming. He could almost feel the warmth of the lamp, see the dust motes dancing in its beam. *“It’s a living thing.”* The man's voice was clearer now, closer. Alfie put a hand out to steady himself against a shelf stacked with canvases.

"Are you alright, son? You've gone a bit pale," the shopkeeper said, his voice laced with concern. "It's the fumes, I expect. Can be a bit much if you're not used to them." Alfie nodded, unable to speak. The shopkeeper picked up a small, square glass bottle filled with a clear, volatile liquid. "Here we are. Best quality. Smells like a pine forest, this does." He held it out. Alfie reached for it, his hand trembling slightly. His fingers closed around the cool, solid glass. He had it. A piece of the puzzle. He paid with one of his secret coins, the transaction feeling momentous, illicit. The shopkeeper wrapped the bottle in brown paper. "You a painter?" he asked conversationally. "No," Alfie said, the word coming out too quickly. "It's... for a job." The lie tasted like ash in his mouth.

He practically fled the shop, the little bell chiming his departure. Out on the street, the damp, salty air felt thin and empty after the rich atmosphere of the shop. He walked home in a daze, one hand clutching the paper-wrapped bottle in his pocket. It felt both dangerous and holy, a relic from a forgotten shrine. He slipped into the house, which was blessedly empty of paternal scrutiny, and went straight to his room. He sat on his narrow bed, the house groaning around him. He unwrapped the bottle. The label was simple: 'Pure Gum Turpentine'. He held it up to the weak light from the window, the liquid inside clear and innocuous. But he knew it was more than that. It was a key. With his heart thudding a slow, heavy rhythm against his ribs, he twisted the metal cap. It came off with a faint squeak. He closed his eyes, lifted the bottle to his nose, and breathed in, deep and deliberate, pulling the past out of the air and into himself.The scent was not just a smell; it was an atmospheric pressure change. As Alfie drew the potent air from the bottle, the grey, cramped bedroom dissolved. The world behind his eyes exploded into colour and warmth. He was small, his head barely reaching the height of a wooden table littered with jars full of coloured water and stiff-bristled brushes. Sunlight, thick and golden, poured through a large, paned window, illuminating millions of dust motes in a swirling, lazy dance. The room was vast, with a ceiling so high it was lost in shadow, and the walls were covered with canvases, some blank, some teeming with half-finished worlds. The air was a rich cocktail of turpentine, linseed oil, and the sweet perfume of a woman who was laughing somewhere just out of sight. Across the room, a man stood before a huge easel. Alfie couldn’t see his face, only the back of his shirt and the focused set of his shoulders. *“Careful, now. It’s a living thing.”* The man’s voice was a low, warm rumble, and he was speaking to him, to the small boy at the table. On the easel was a painting, a seascape of impossible energy. A wave, captured at its peak, was rendered in a hundred shades of blue and green, its crest a brilliant, furious white. And in the corner of the canvas, a single, defiant splash of crimson. Not the dark, sickening red of the docks, but a clean, vibrant vermilion, the colour of a poppy in the sun. It was the most beautiful thing he had ever seen. A hand, a man’s hand, reached out and ruffled his hair. He felt the phantom touch, a ghost of affection so profound it made his chest ache.

The intensity of the sensation was a physical blow. Alfie gasped, stumbling backward, his leg catching the side of his narrow bed. The glass bottle slipped from his numb fingers, not shattering but rolling onto the thin mattress, its precious, volatile contents spilling in a dark, spreading stain on the cheap fabric. He scrambled to his feet, his head spinning, the vivid, sun-drenched studio collapsing back into the grim reality of his little box room. The contrast was a physical pain, a sudden, brutal exile from a paradise he hadn't known he'd lost. He was shaking, not with fear, but with a grief so immense it felt like a part of his own body. He threw open his window, letting the cold, salty wind rush in, but it couldn't scour the scent of the studio away. It was inside him now. He had not just remembered something; he had been somewhere. And he had been loved there. The knowledge was a small, flickering candle in the vast, dark emptiness of his past.

The next two days at the marina were spent in a fugue state. The methodical work of priming the hull, the steady slap of the brush, the smooth application of white, became an automatic process that his body performed while his mind was elsewhere, lost in the sun-drenched studio. The world of the docks, once so overwhelming in its grim reality, now seemed flimsy and grey, a poor imitation of life compared to the vibrant memory he held. He was quieter than ever, but it was a different kind of quiet. Not the silence of a frightened animal, but the focused silence of a watchmaker examining a complex and delicate mechanism. Hemlock watched him, his pale eyes missing nothing. He saw the way Alfie’s gaze would drift off into the middle distance, the way he would sometimes stop, brush poised, as if listening for a voice no one else could hear. On the third day, they were to apply the first coat of colour – a deep, classic navy blue. Hemlock mixed the paint, stirring a tin of red oxide into the base to give it a richer tone. As the first swirl of red mixed with the blue, Alfie flinched, a sharp, involuntary jerk of his shoulders.

Hemlock stopped stirring and looked at him, his expression unreadable. “Something wrong with the colour, boy?” he rasped. Alfie shook his head quickly, his gaze fixed on the swirl of red, which was no longer a threatening splash but a component, a part of a formula. He thought of the vermilion on the canvas, a deliberate, beautiful choice. “No,” Alfie said, his voice surprisingly steady. “It’s just… how do you know what colours to mix? To get the right one?” The question hung in the air between them, oddly academic in the grimy, practical world of the boatyard. Hemlock stared at him for a long moment, then gave a short, humourless laugh. “Experience. You try things. You make mistakes. You learn what a colour wants to be.” He handed Alfie a clean brush. “It’s not magic. It’s just work. Now paint.” But as Alfie dipped his brush into the rich, dark blue, he knew the old man was wrong. It wasn't just work. It was a kind of magic. He had been there when it was being made.

That evening, he didn’t just place the coins on the table. He waited. Mr. Davison came into the hallway from the kitchen, stopping short when he saw Alfie standing there. The two of them stood in the gloom, a silent, awkward tableau. “I took some of the money,” Alfie said, the confession rushing out of him. “From the other day. For myself.” He expected anger, a tirade, maybe even the back of a hand. Instead, Robert Davison merely looked at his own worn, empty hands, then back at Alfie. “A man earns his pay,” he said, his voice a low rumble. “What he does with it is his own business. So long as he remembers what he owes.” He brushed past Alfie and went into the front room, the rustle of his newspaper a familiar sound of retreat. But it was a different retreat. It was a concession. Alfie had asserted himself as an earner, a contributor, and in Mr. Davison’s brutal, simple world, that had meaning. It was the beginning of a treaty.

He found Clara in her room, mending a tear in a sailcloth bag with a thick needle and waxed thread. The scent of turpentine still clung faintly to him, and she wrinkled her nose as he came in. "You smell like a factory." He sat on the edge of her bed, the secret he was carrying too heavy to bear alone any longer. He couldn't tell her about the visions, the flashes of another life. It sounded like madness. So he told her a version of the truth, the most solid piece he could hold onto. “I think my father was a painter,” he said, the words feeling huge and strange in his mouth. Clara stopped sewing. She looked at him, her sharp blue eyes searching his face, weighing his words. She didn't laugh or ask him how he could possibly know. She accepted his statement as a new fact in the world. "A painter?" she repeated. "Like, houses?" "No," Alfie said, his voice gaining confidence. "Like pictures. An artist." He thought of the roaring seascape, the defiant splash of red. "I think he was an artist."

Clara put down her needle. Her mind, always so quick and practical, was already leaping ahead, mapping out a course of action. The past was a puzzle, and Clara loved puzzles. “Right,” she said, her tone suddenly brisk and businesslike. “So. An artist in Portsmouth. What was his name?” The question hit Alfie like a physical blow. He stared at her, the candle of hope inside him flickering violently. "I don't know," he whispered. He had no name for the man whose hand had ruffled his hair, whose voice echoed in his head. He was just a warm, low rumble and a focused back. The blankness of it, the sheer scale of what he didn't know, was suddenly overwhelming. Seeing the despair on his face, Clara's expression softened. "Okay," she said, her voice gentle but firm. "Okay. That's a problem, but it's not the end of the world. We just have to start somewhere else." She stood up and pulled a dusty book from her shelf – a local history of Portsmouth. "People don't just disappear. Not completely. There are records. Lists. Maybe the local papers have reviews of art shows. The city art gallery keeps records of exhibitions. We start there. We go on Saturday." She looked at him, her fierce loyalty a shield against the vast, terrifying blankness of his past. "We'll find him, Alfie," she said, and it wasn't a guess. It was a promise.The days between the discovery in his room and the promised trip to the library were a new kind of purgatory for Alfie. He went to the marina, he worked, he returned home. On the surface, the rhythm was the same. He and Hemlock finished the navy blue topcoat on the hull, the boat now looking sharp and seaworthy, a thing reborn. Alfie’s arms and back settled into a state of permanent, background ache, a dull song of labour he was growing accustomed to. But his mind was a storm. The image of the sun-drenched studio and the sound of the woman’s laugh were a constant counterpoint to the grey skies and the cries of the gulls. He worked with a fierce, divided focus, one part of him meticulously applying the thick, glossy paint, the other part sifting through the single, perfect memory, turning it over and over, searching for a new facet, another clue. He had become a keeper of a secret so profound it made the rest of his life feel like a poorly constructed stage set.

On Friday, as Hemlock paid him, the old man held his gaze a moment longer than usual. The boat was finished, gleaming in the weak sunlight. "Good work, boy," Hemlock rasped, the praise so unexpected it felt like a physical shock. "There's a ketch coming in next week for scraping. More of the same. If you want it." The offer of future work, of a place to be next week, was an anchor in the swirling chaos of his thoughts. "Yes," Alfie said, his voice clear. "I want it." He was a boy who sanded hulls and painted boats. That was a fact. But he was also someone else, someone from a warm, bright room, and he needed to find out who that person was.

Saturday morning arrived, grey and damp, but to Alfie, it felt charged with a brilliant, nervous electricity. Clara was all business, wolfing down toast in the kitchen, a tattered A-to-Z map of Portsmouth spread on the table. Mr. Davison was mercifully absent, having left early for one of the ex-servicemen’s clubs he frequented. As Alfie and Clara slipped out of the house, Mrs. Davison pressed a small paper bag into his hand. "For your lunch," she whispered, her eyes full of a worry she couldn't articulate. It was the first time she had ever done such a thing. Alfie felt a strange pang of affection for this quiet, frightened woman who navigated the minefield of her own home with small, placating gestures.

The Central Library was a grand, imposing Victorian building of red brick and carved stone, a temple of knowledge that seemed to belong to a different, more optimistic city than the one Alfie knew. Inside, the air was hushed and warm, smelling of floor polish and millions of pages of slowly decaying paper. It was the quietest place Alfie had ever been. He felt clumsy and loud, his work boots heavy on the polished floor, conscious of the boatyard dust that still clung to his clothes. They were directed to the local history floor, a solemn room where old men in tweed jackets slept in armchairs and a stern-looking librarian presided over a counter like a judge.

The first hurdle presented itself immediately. "What name are you looking for?" the librarian asked, her spectacles perched on the end of her nose. Alfie’s throat went dry. He looked at Clara, who stepped forward, a picture of unflappable confidence. "We're not sure of the name," she said smoothly. "We're researching local artists. Specifically painters. Active around, say, fifteen to twenty years ago." The librarian’s eyebrow arched in skepticism. "That's a rather broad field. Are we talking seascapes? Portraits? Abstract?" Alfie thought of the impossible wave on the canvas. "Seascapes," he said, his own voice surprising him. The librarian gave him a long, assessing look, then seemed to relent. "The exhibition catalogues are over there," she said, pointing to a row of bound volumes. "And the newspaper archives are on microfiche. The machines are in the back."

For two hours, they sat at a heavy oak table, poring over the catalogues. The pages were filled with names, lists of artworks, and grainy, black-and-white reproductions that looked like grey smudges. The sheer number of forgotten artists was dizzying. Each name was a dead end, a life's work reduced to a few lines of type in a dusty book. Alfie felt his initial, frantic hope begin to cool into a familiar, leaden despair. He was looking for a ghost in a graveyard of ghosts. It was a fool's errand. The warm studio began to feel like a dream again, a cruel fantasy his mind had concocted.

"This is getting us nowhere," Clara declared, slamming a volume shut with a puff of dust. "We need to see the work. Pictures. Not just names." She marched them over to the microfiche readers, a row of beige, humming machines that looked like relics from a forgotten future. After a brief, confusing lesson from the librarian, Clara was threading spools of film with practiced efficiency. The past scrolled by on the small, glowing screen: headlines about council disputes, football results, advertisements for washing machines. Alfie turned the handle, his eyes burning from the flickering light, watching years of other people's lives flash before him. They scanned the arts pages, finding reviews of exhibitions, interviews with sculptors, but nothing resonated. Nothing sparked the fire of recognition.

He was ready to give up. The stale, recycled air of the library was beginning to feel suffocating. His body ached from a week of labour, and his mind ached with a deeper, more profound exhaustion. "Clara, this is pointless," he murmured, his head sinking into his hands. "It's not pointless," she shot back, her voice a low, fierce whisper. "We're just looking in the wrong way. One more. Then we'll stop." She took a spool from a box marked 'Spring, 17 Years Ago' and threaded it onto the machine with a sharp, determined snap. The first few frames were of a local election. Then a flower show. Then an article appeared, headlined: ‘Portsmouth Arts Collective Aims to Capture the Spirit of the Solent’. Alfie sat up a little straighter. Underneath the headline was a photograph.

It was a group shot, taken at what looked like an exhibition opening. A dozen people holding wine glasses, smiling for the camera. Alfie scanned their faces, feeling a familiar wave of disappointment. They were strangers. All of them. His gaze drifted to the edge of the frame, to where the composition fell apart. Two people, a man and a woman, were caught in conversation, their bodies turned away from the main group. The man's back was mostly to the camera, but Alfie’s breath caught in his throat. He knew that back. He knew the set of those shoulders, the slight tilt of the head as he listened to his companion. It was an impossible, absolute recognition, a truth that bypassed his eyes and went straight to the core of his being. It was the man from the studio.

"Clara," he whispered, his voice cracking. His hand, smudged with the faint ghost of navy blue paint, rose and pointed a trembling finger at the screen. "There." Clara leaned in, her eyes narrowing as she followed his gaze. She saw the man, and the woman beside him. The woman's face was turned towards the man, her expression lost in the grainy image, but she was clearly laughing. Clara slowly, carefully, wound the handle, scrolling down until the caption appeared, stark and clear in the greenish light. *'Local artists celebrate the launch. Alfie stared at the words. *Julian Croft.* The name was strange and perfect. It sounded like stone and soft earth. *Elara Vance.* He mouthed the name, and the sound of the woman’s laugh from his memory echoed in his head, clearer than ever. Julian and Elara. They were not ghosts. They were not a dream. They were real people, captured on a piece of film seventeen years ago, their names typed out for the world to see. He looked from the names to the grainy image, at the man with the familiar back and the woman who was laughing, and felt the vast, foggy emptiness of his past begin to burn away, replaced by the first, terrifying, and brilliant light of a new sun.The world contracted to the small, glowing screen of the microfiche reader. The humming of the machine was the only sound in the universe. *Julian Croft. Elara Vance.* The names were not just letters; they were solid objects, stones he could hold in his hand. They had weight. They had history. Alfie’s breath hitched, and he felt a dizzying sense of vertigo, as if the floor of the library had fallen away, leaving him suspended over the vast, black chasm of his own forgotten past. He reached out a hand, his fingers pressing against the cool glass of the screen, as if he could touch the grainy image, as if he could will the man with the familiar shoulders to turn around. "Got him," Clara whispered, her voice a low, triumphant hiss beside him. Her practicality was an anchor. While Alfie was spiralling, she was plotting. Her finger tapped the screen next to the second name. "And her. Elara Vance. 'Fellow painter'. Wonder who she was." She wound the film forward with a decisive click, then back again, her eyes scanning the text for any other mention, any scrap of additional information. There was nothing. Just that one photograph, that one caption. A single, frozen moment from seventeen years ago. Clara switched the machine off. The light died, plunging the names back into darkness, but they were seared onto Alfie’s mind. "Right," she said, her voice returning to its normal volume, startling in the library’s oppressive hush. "That's enough for today. Let's go."

Walking out of the library was like stepping into a different city. The weak afternoon sun breaking through the clouds struck the wet slate roofs, making them gleam with a silvery light he had never noticed before. The familiar grime on the brickwork seemed to resolve itself into a hundred different shades of ochre and brown. He was seeing Portsmouth through his father’s eyes. This was Julian Croft’s city. These were the streets he walked, this was the light he saw and, perhaps, tried to capture. The screech of the gulls sounded less like lost souls and more like a wild, chaotic orchestra. "He was a painter," Alfie said aloud, the words tasting new and strange. He wasn't asking; he was telling the world, telling himself. "He painted the sea."

The thought was a jolt of pure, terrifying hope. That the studio might still exist, that the man himself might be somewhere in this city, was too much to process. "Or he might be gone," Alfie said, the words a necessary ballast against the rising tide of optimism.
"Maybe," Clara conceded. "People move. Or… other things. But we can find out. The gallery, the one in the paper, the Aspex. It’s still there. We can ask. And we can look for her, too. Elara Vance. The return to the Davisons' house felt like a descent. The smell of stale air and boiled vegetables was a physical weight, pressing down on the new, fragile sense of self that was blooming inside him.
